snippet: A 36-year-old brought to the country from Mexico as a child can be admitted to the state bar, the California Supreme Court said. But, under federal law, no law firm can legally hire him.
abstract: California Supreme Court rules unanimously that a law passed by the state Legislature allows qualified applicants to be admitted to the state bar regardless of their immigration status; what ruling does not address is fact that under federal law, no law firm, business or public agency can legally hire illegal immigrants; case highlights complicated patchwork of immigration laws emerging as Congress remains stalled on overhaul of federal laws and states and courts step in.
lead_paragraph: A 36-year-old brought to the country from Mexico as a child can be admitted to the state bar, the California Supreme Court said. But, under federal law, no law firm can legally hire him.

headline.main: Allowed to Join the Bar, but Not to Take a Job
headline.print_headline: Allowed to Join the Bar, but Not to Take a Job
